title: Report: Plane that crashed into Florida mobile home park had no obvious malfunction | News & Features
text:
FORT LAUDERDALE, Fla. -- The Piper Cherokee that crashed into a Lake Worth mobile home park on Oct. 13, killing two, had no obvious mechanical malfunctions, according to a preliminary accident report released Thursday.
That leaves federal investigators with the difficult task of trying to find out why the pilot, Dan Shalloway, 64, of Riviera Beach, lost control while a minute or two from landing at Palm Beach County Park Airport near Lantana.
Shalloway, the plane's only occupant, made no distress call so investigators don't know the exact nature of his emergency.
However, the report notes he made an "S" turn while near the airport, indicating he encountered some sort of trouble before he could line up with the runway.
"A witness observed the airplane flying overhead and watched as it made the 'S'-turn, followed by a steep right 180-degree turn and descend into a mobile home park," wrote Dan Boggs, an air safety investigator with the National Transportation Safety Board.
The 1973 single-engine Piper Cherokee crashed into the Mar-Mak Colony Club mobile home park at 5:33 p.m. that Tuesday. Shalloway and Banny Galicia, 21, who was in a mobile home, were killed.
Whether Shalloway was distracted, suffered a medical problem or encountered some other crisis may never be known. The four-seat plane burst into fire and was so badly burned that investigators were unable to read the cockpit instruments.
However, they were able to ascertain that the plane's control surfaces, including ailerons and rudders, appeared to be in working order prior to the crash. Also, there were no obvious problems with the engine, according to the report.
Maintenance records indicated the plane received a thorough annual inspection on May 25. The plane was owned by Flyers Inc. of Boynton Beach.
On the day of the accident, Shalloway took off from the Lantana airport and flew to the Kissimmee Gateway Airport, near Orlando. He had the plane refueled with 20 gallons of aviation gasoline.
He took off seven hours later. Although no flight plan was filed, air traffic controllers communicated with him and monitored his progress via radar.
While approaching Lantana, Shalloway announced to other planes on a common radio frequency that he was three miles east of the airport and planning to land on Runway 15, which runs to the southeast.
Shalloway made one more radio call, to advise other pilots he was perpendicular to the runway and close to final approach. "No other communications were received from the pilot," Boggs wrote in the report.
According to Federal Aviation Administration records, Shalloway was issued a private pilot license on May 4, 2012, and passed a required medical exam on Sept. 23. At the time of that exam, Shalloway reported he had a total of 250 hours of flight experience.
